articles.headline: In a Wary Arctic, Norway Starts to See Russian Spies Everywhere
articles.snippet: Other European countries are, too, blurring the line between vigilance and paranoia.
articles.abstract: Other European countries are, too, blurring the line between vigilance and paranoia.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Erika Solomon and Henrik Pryser Libell

articles.headline: Mass Migrant Crossing Floods Texas Border Facilities
articles.snippet: The arrival of up to 1,000 migrants, the latest big group to have crossed the border, was one of the largest single crossings in recent years in West Texas, which has seen a surge in migration.
articles.abstract: The arrival of up to 1,000 migrants, the latest big group to have crossed the border, was one of the largest single crossings in recent years in West Texas, which has seen a surge in migration.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — After nightfall on Sunday, hundreds of migrants stepped across the Rio Grande and into El Paso, a caravan of people mainly from Nicaragua whose crossing was among the largest in recent years along the West Texas border.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, J. David Goodman and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Two Decades After 9/11 Inquiry, a Similar Plan for Covid Stalls in Congress
articles.snippet: The 9/11 Commission prompted a national reckoning over the Sept. 11 attacks. But some experts fear that the chance to create an independent panel to investigate the pandemic response is slipping away.
articles.abstract: The 9/11 Commission prompted a national reckoning over the Sept. 11 attacks. But some experts fear that the chance to create an independent panel to investigate the pandemic response is slipping away.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation was reeling from an unfathomable number of deaths. Politicians were pointing fingers, asking why the United States had been so ill-prepared for a lethal threat. Congress, defying the White House, ordered an independent investigation.

articles.headline: FTX’s Sam Bankman-Fried Is Arrested in the Bahamas
articles.snippet: A statement by the government of the Bahamas said Mr. Bankman-Fried was arrested after prosecutors in the United States filed criminal charges.
articles.abstract: A statement by the government of the Bahamas said Mr. Bankman-Fried was arrested after prosecutors in the United States filed criminal charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the arrest of FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, William K. Rashbaum and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: In FTX Collapse, Binance Sees a Chance to Become the New Face of Crypto
articles.snippet: Sam Bankman-Fried and Changpeng Zhao were archrivals. With FTX gone, Binance, the world’s biggest crypto exchange, is trying to step into the void.
articles.abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried and Changpeng Zhao were archrivals. With FTX gone, Binance, the world’s biggest crypto exchange, is trying to step into the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early November, just days before the cryptocurrency exchange FTX filed for bankruptcy, its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, reached out to his archrival, Changpeng Zhao, to ask for help.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: The Parents in the Middle of FTX’s Collapse
articles.snippet: The FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried’s mother and father, who teach at Stanford Law School, are under scrutiny for their connections to their son’s crypto business.
articles.abstract: The FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried’s mother and father, who teach at Stanford Law School, are under scrutiny for their connections to their son’s crypto business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update: Sam Bankman-Fried was released from federal custody on Thursday under bail conditions that include a $250 million bond secured by his parents’ home.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Lora Kelley and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: The Rich Get College Subsidies While the Student Debt Debate Goes On
articles.snippet: As debt relief for student loan borrowers faces scrutiny, wealthy families can amass millions of dollars in tax-favored 529 college savings plans.
articles.abstract: As debt relief for student loan borrowers faces scrutiny, wealthy families can amass millions of dollars in tax-favored 529 college savings plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: As Covid Spreads Fast, Beijing Isn’t in Lockdown. But It Feels Like It.
articles.snippet: Almost no one is venturing out even after an easing of pandemic measures. Cold and flu medicines are scarce, but food supplies appear adequate.
articles.abstract: Almost no one is venturing out even after an easing of pandemic measures. Cold and flu medicines are scarce, but food supplies appear adequate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Restaurants have closed because too many staff members have tested positive for Covid. The usually ubiquitous food delivery workers zipping through traffic on their scooters have nearly vanished because of infections. Pharmacies have been emptied of cold medicine, and supermarkets have been running low on the essentials such as disinfectant solution and antibacterial wipes.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and David Pierson

articles.headline: Inflation Cooled Notably in November, Good News for the Fed
articles.snippet: Consumer Price Index data reinforces that inflation is beginning to slow down just ahead of the Federal Reserve’s December rate decision.
articles.abstract: Consumer Price Index data reinforces that inflation is beginning to slow down just ahead of the Federal Reserve’s December rate decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation slowed more sharply than expected in November, an encouraging sign for both Federal Reserve officials and consumers that 18 months of rapid and unrelenting price increases are beginning to meaningfully abate.
